title: 111_hr4897
content: The Act may be cited as the "Drivers Accelerated Interest Deductibility Act of 2010" or the "Drivers AID Act". Congress finds that the economic health of the United States relies on a strong automotive industry, historically accounting for 20% of retail spending. Automotive sales peaked in 2006-2008 but have since declined, with annual rates below 10,000,000 units. The automotive new vehicle dealers industry in the United States made significant contributions to the national economy in 2008. With approximately 20,000 dealers, the industry generated $576 billion in total sales, accounting for 14.6% of total retail sales. Employing over 1 million people, dealerships had an average of 53 employees per dealership, with an average annual salary of $48,963. This resulted in a national payroll of over $52 billion and millions in tax revenue for State and local governments. The new-vehicle dealer industry contributes significantly to the national economy by generating billions in sales, employing over a million people, and providing millions in tax revenue. Preserving the viability of dealerships is crucial for the success of automobile manufacturers, consumer confidence, and the automotive manufacturing industry. Interest deductions for automobile loan debt were deductible for Federal income tax purposes for 73 years until Congress ended the deduction in 1986. Payment of nonmortgage interest payments, like automobile loan debt, was deductible for Federal income tax for 73 years until Congress ended the deduction in 1986. The deduction for interest on indebtedness incurred to acquire a passenger car or light truck was eliminated by Congress in 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subparagraph (G) regarding qualified vehicle interest for vehicles acquired when the national unemployment rate is at least 7 percent. Qualified vehicle interest is defined as interest on debt incurred to acquire a qualified vehicle. The term 'qualified vehicle interest' refers to interest on debt incurred to acquire a qualified vehicle, with limitations on the amount of interest that can be considered and the period it covers. The term 'qualified vehicle interest' refers to interest on debt incurred to acquire a qualified vehicle, with limitations on the amount of interest that can be considered and the period it covers. A qualified vehicle is a motor vehicle acquired for personal use, not for resale, meeting specific criteria under the Clean Air Act. The term 'motor vehicle' refers to any vehicle manufactured primarily for public road use with at least 4 wheels, weighing 6,000 pounds or less, and classified as a passenger automobile or light truck under the Clean Air Act regulations. The text discusses the definitions of 'automobile', 'passenger automobile', 'light truck', and 'manufacturer' as per regulations under the Clean Air Act. It also mentions the average national unemployment rate calculation and a deduction allowed for qualified vehicle interest in computing adjusted gross income. The effective date for the amendments made by this section is also specified. The deduction for qualified vehicle interest under section 163(h)(5) applies to vehicles acquired on or after January 1, 2008.
